an4.114:1.1: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an4.114:1.3: A royal bull elephant listens, destroys, endures, and goes fast.
an4.114:2.1: And how does a royal bull elephant listen?
an4.114:2.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant pays heed, pays attention, engages wholeheartedly, and lends an ear to whatever task the elephant trainer has it do,
an4.114:2.3: whether or not it has done it before.
an4.114:2.5: That’s how a royal bull elephant listens.
an4.114:3.1: And how does a royal bull elephant destroy?
an4.114:3.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle destroys elephants with their riders, horses with their riders, chariots and charioteers, and foot soldiers.
an4.114:3.3: That’s how a royal bull elephant destroys.
an4.114:4.1: And how does a royal bull elephant endure?
an4.114:4.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle endures being struck by spears, swords, arrows, and axes; it endures the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals.
an4.114:4.3: That’s how a royal bull elephant endures.
an4.114:5.1: And how does a royal bull elephant go fast?
an4.114:5.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant swiftly goes in whatever direction the elephant trainer sends it,
an4.114:5.3: whether or not it has been there before.
an4.114:5.5: That’s how a royal bull elephant goes fast.
an4.114:5.6: A royal bull elephant with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an4.114:6.1: In the same way, a mendicant with four factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an4.114:6.3: A mendicant listens, destroys, endures, and goes fast.
an4.114:7.1: And how does a mendicant listen?
an4.114:7.2: It’s when a mendicant pays heed, pays attention, engages wholeheartedly, and lends an ear when the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One is being taught.
an4.114:8.1: And how does a mendicant destroy?
an4.114:8.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
an4.114:9.1: And how does a mendicant endure?
an4.114:9.2: It’s when a mendicant endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and they put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
an4.114:10.1: And how does a mendicant go fast?
an4.114:10.2: It’s when a mendicant swiftly goes in the direction they’ve never gone before in all this long time; that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
an4.114:10.3: That’s how a mendicant goes fast.
an4.114:10.4: A mendicant with these four factors … is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
